success.question_text:
Where did Fiona the Frog live? In the ________

Below type the word that completes the answer.

stimulus_2.text:
Koala Ken

Koala Ken was a volunteer ranger in a state forest. He liked to help out. He wore a ranger’s badge on his special cap that protected his head from the sun and the rain. 


Ken was doing his best to keep the bush animals calm. They were getting upset.


‘My shade trees are all being chopped down to make way for houses!’ growled Billy the Bandicoot.


‘My stream is going dry because people are using the water for their lawns,’ moaned Patsy the Platypus.

stimulus_3.text:
‘My favourite leaves are withering and going brown,’ sighed Pete the Possum.


‘Someone has covered much of the ground with cement and I cannot find ants any more,’ added Eve the Echidna.


‘My lake is full of speeding boats and it’s no longer safe for swimming,’ grumbled Fiona the Frog.


Ken listened to each animal in turn. He rubbed his paw across his hot forehead. He was thinking. What could he do?

A great big blue question mark emerged above his head. It grew bigger and bigger, brighter and brighter.

Then Ken smiled.

success.question_text: Which word would best replace upset as it is used in the text?

success.question_text: What type of animal is a chameleon?

stimulus_2.text:
Animal survival

There are three basic groups of living things—fungi and bacteria, plants and creatures. All living creatures have developed to suit their environment. Many birds are green, such as some parrots, to suit the colours of the tree canopies in which they live. Some, such as owls, are grey like the branches or bark of trees. Others are brown, such as snakes, like the earth or rocks.

In the natural world there are all sorts of perils. Adaptation to their environment helps creatures to survive these dangers.

stimulus_3.text: The small lizard-like reptile, the chameleon, is an amazing example of adaptation. It can change colour quickly to blend in with the surroundings at any particular time. Other creatures change colours more slowly. As the seasons change, the Arctic fox changes the colour of its coat. In the spring and summer, it has a dark coat, to match the brown dirt in its environment. In the autumn and winter, it turns white, to match the surrounding snow.

stimulus_4.text: In addition to background-matching colouration, many animals have distinctive designs on their bodies that serve to conceal them. These might be spots, stripes or a group of patches. They may match the background of the animal’s surroundings. For example, animals, such as small deer, that inhabit areas with tall, vertical grass often have long, vertical stripes.

success.question_text: What body feature would be suitable for animals that inhabit tall grass?
